title: Impressive!
body: I have been registered at this surgery for over 28 years. In that time, I have seen many positive changes. The team at this surgery are fantastic. Doctors and nurses provide excellent care of their patients. They are very knowledgeable, patient, caring and understanding. The admin team work extremely hard, and although sometimes it is difficult to get through on the phone, please be patient as they busy and doing their best. Today I felt compelled to write this review not only because they are a great GP surgery, but also because a member of the nursing team went beyond their call of duty. I felt very touched that they remembered a conversation we had during a phone appointment, and they acted on it to help meet the needs of an elderly and vulnerable person.  You are all doing a brilliant job.  Thank you!

title: A little disappointed.
body:
Attended as I had sliced the tip of my finger and it had been bleeding on and off for an hour. The staff were very nice but I feel underestimated the dressing required, maybe because it appeared to have stopped bleeding. The dressing of choice was a "Cosmopor E 7.2cmx5cm and unfortunately on the way home. although elevated, my finger started bleeding again. Consequently the dressing fell off and I was left trying to staunch the flow half way down Poulton Street. 
When I reached home I used one of the extra dressings I was given and reinforced it with kitchen towel and sellotape.
Although the injury was minor I don't think the potential for a secondary bleed was appreciated even though I had advised the staff that I do get "White finger" which obviously has an influence on the bleeding capacity when it warms up.
This is not meant as a complaint, merely a gentle comment to bear in mind  for future fingers.

author: Juniper27
title: Cognitive Behavioural Therapy
body:
I've recently completed a course of six cognitive behavioural therapy sessions at the Oxford Street branch of Let's Talk Wellbeing in Nottingham.  
Since attempting suicide during university in 2013 I have been struggling with depression, anxiety and suicidal thoughts and have sought help in the form of both medication, and talking therapy/counselling, both of which have had no effect in treating my depression and as a result I haven't been able to pursue my goals and live a fulfilling life. Throughout this time CBT has been recommended by mental health workers and doctors, but I have struggled to access it due to waiting lists and being transferred between different mental health teams and services. In November 2019 I self referred myself to Let's Talk about a month later had a telephone assessment and a CBT appointment in January, at a date, time and location that I could choose.  
I constantly found the sessions to be unstructured, sparse (in content) and inconsistent. For example, a homework would be set one week, and treated of little importance the next (not linking it to any particular goal, skill etc.) and wouldn't be brought up until I mentioned it, but at other times when I struggled to complete the homework I would be made to feel guilty, and the therapist would continue assigning the same homework rather than trying something different. From the homework that I was assigned, I did not acquire any new skills that were effective coping strategies or techniques that lead to an improved behavioural outcome.  
When I did communicate my negative thoughts, the therapist didn't challenge them, but enabled them in many cases. For example, when I explained that I was anxious about making an academic appeal with the university "because I feel like I have let down the university and wasted the opportunities that they have given me, even though they have already made plenty of allowances for me", I thought to myself that I had finally said something that might be "usable" and that we would start doing the cognitive behavioural thing I was hoping for , but they didn't do anything to challenge that particular thought pattern and the avoidance that it leads to but instead treated it as if it was a casual conversation and expressed sympathy for that view point.  
The therapist didn't support me in a long-term goal that I have been struggling with for a number of years (it is one which I have previously made successful initial steps in but struggled after that). When we discussed the problem, there was absolutely no challenging of the negative thinking that surrounds it.  
I often struggled to express myself during the sessions and felt judged for this. It may have been partly due to the fact that I wasn't able to establish a relationship of trust with the therapist in the small number of sessions, but I think that this was contributed to by ineffective use of questioning by the therapist. Whilst I understand that open-ended questions probably have an important role in avoiding dictating to patients and giving them freedom to express themselves, the reliance on that particular style of questioning didn't work for me. As somebody who is introverted and has difficulty when talking about emotive and sensitive subjects I have an instinct to give the least that is possible when asked general, open-ended questions (not sure if they were technically open-ended questions as I'm not an expert on questions but that is how I perceived them as they seemed to lack precision). To me it seems clear how this open question style might disadvantage a range of personality traits, behaviour patterns (i.e. avoidance), people with differing abilities to express themselves for a variety of reasons and I feel that this where I struggled with counselling/talking therapy and was hoping that CBT would offer a more structured and investigative approach so that I would feel supported in communicating more of my thoughts.  
I'm not saying that as a patient I should take a passive role in the CBT, but asking the right questions in order to gain an understanding and insight is surely the bread and butter of being able to help to find a solution to any problem. I've had a quick browse through some of the other stories on this website about Nottingham IAPT and at least one other person describes the sense of the therapist "not getting to the root cause" of an issue.  
Being asked "What can I do for you?", "what would you like to get out of this session?" etc. at the beginning of each session contributed to a sense of non-continuity, and that we weren't working towards goals and developing skills and made me question whether they remembered what was said in the previous session or whether they had taken adequate notes.  
During the sessions they would ask how they were doing as I'm sure they could sense that I was struggling to communicate but this just added an additional role that I had to carry out when I was already struggling with trying to "perform" what seems to be required as a patient (I've written more about this idea later). I should add that I wasn't deliberately withholding information from the therapist, it's only after a period a reflection that I have some sense of why I acted in a certain way and what could have helped. It's disappointing that the therapist didn't seem to have the skills or framework to analyse the situation and find potential solutions for my lack of communication and instead seemed to judge me for it.  
When a discussion did manage to arise in the dialogue that we had did not contribute to any new understanding on my part. I didn't learn anything insightful about my mental state or thought process from the therapist, and often it felt like the responses were rehearsed rather than being relevant to my situation - I would agree with the assessments but they were quite general and something that I had already recognised in myself, and these assessments weren't really linked to anything else, I wasn't given the skills or techniques to challenge these particular thought or behaviour patterns.  
They kept telling me that "CBT wasn't suitable for me" or that "I wasn't ready", without explaining why or what the alternatives might be. They would often contradict himself and retract things that were said in a previous session. The therapist complained that they were "doing too much work", adding to my feelings of guilt and the sense that I can never be helped, and if they were doing any work I didn't feel like I was benefiting from it. The sessions would often leave me in tears (which I expected to happen as it was advised that this might be a possibility on the appointment letter) but I wasn't given any techniques to deal with this and it wasn't used as an opportunity for learning.  
There wasn't anywhere I could go to collect myself and calm down when I left the sessions in tears, apart from the only bathroom which was a single-stalled bathroom which opened directly into the hallway. I was lead to believe that I could potentially have more sessions if I wasn't making any progress, but was discharged because I didn't make any progress.  
After each of the interactions I've had with mental health workers I come away with a sense that there seems to be some specific performance that they are looking for, even though I am unable to quite put my finger on what that performance might be, my ability to carry out this performance seems to be a necessary condition attached to the quality of care provided. I was finally given a clue to what this might look like at the end of the final session (I was trying to make sense of all of the contradictions being made so was losing focus of what they were saying) but the therapist talked about me re-referring myself in several months time and had ideas about what those therapy sessions might look like - saying something to the effect of "You're going to learn things about yourself which you won't like/ you will learn that you think things about yourself and won't understand why you think that way/ it will be difficult but when you are ready you will share with other people". I found it fascinating how they didn't seem to have planned the next week's session but was able to glimpse months into the future to tell me what my therapy would look like. It seems to be at odds with the sense of flexibility which I suspect they were trying to create (depending on which week it was), but which was ultimately an illusion.  
Even as someone who suffers from persistent negative thoughts, I would never have thought of my self as helpless and usually retain a sense of hope that things will improve, which is what leads me to seek help from mental health services and self-refer for CBT. But unfortunately the repeated, unsuccessful interactions with mental health "professionals" is increasingly engendering this mindset - I'm starting to get the sense that I am trapped in a web and the more that I do to try and escape, the more tangled I am becoming and it is has added a new element to suicidal ideation. Increasingly I am thinking that I am in the wrong for hoping or believing that anyone can help me and the deleterious effects on my mental health that I am experiencing are a natural outcome of such a foolish assumption.  
The service which was supposed to alleviate my long-term mental health issues and has caused more harm than benefit, and I am left with little to no support in the aftermath. I went into the treatment with an open mind and determined to make the most of the opportunity only to be completely disappointed and let down by the service. I have wasted time which I can never get back and feel like I've drifted further from my goals than I have ever been during the course of these sessions.  
Whether it's an institutional problem, an academic problem or simply one of quality assurance it's safe to say that until there is a (visible) system of accountability for mental health workers then I believe little has changed since the time when lobotomies were a common treatment for mental health patients.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Miki nr1
title: My Mum
body:
One Sunday in March, my 95 year old Mother, Annie, was rushed into Royal Cornwall Hospital Truro, after a severe stroke.  
My wife and I were notified on the Monday by a wonderful Speciality Doctor Dr Joe. he explained everything in great detail the end result being she would not survive this and that she was not expected to live more than a few Days.  
As we live 500 miles away we dropped everything and drove to Cornwall.  
When we arrived at The Hospital (having notified them beforehand) the reception from the Staff on PHOENIX WARD was nothing short of incredible !!  
How much adulation my wife and I have for these great people cannot be measured.  
Dr JOE and his team are terrific human beings so caring in the circumstances and in our opinion, went over and above to make sure my Mum was as comfortable as she could possibly be during her last few days with us. they kept us informed of the situation every day and Dr Joe spent time with us for which we will be eternally grateful.  
The hospital arranged a bed for my wife to stay with mum in her last few days and she was treated with the utmost care and respect.  
Once again I would like to thank them all and may God Bless every one them and keep them Safe.

title: Orthopaedic
body: My operation has been cancelled for Monday 6th April.would have been brilliant to get this operation done because need 6 weeks of work but by the time they start operating again I will only be off 3 weeks from work .

title: Generally good
body: I have been with this practice for a number of years and I think that it is run very well.  Booking an appointment is easy so long as one appreciates how many appointments can fit into a day.  I have been helped over several serious hurdles by this practice and have always found the staff to be polite and helpful.  They always keep their composure when confronted by rude patients, which is often.  The time it takes to get them on the phone can be quite long but watching them when in the surgery shows that they are constantly answering the phone.  All in all I would compliment them on their resilience doing what is not an easy job.  Well done!

title: Doctors that care
body:
I have seen all three doctors at this practice and can honestly say that you are never rushed out of the door. 
The doctors listen and are very thorough, they deliver a high level of care.

author: Healing patient
title: Care and compassion during a time of uncertainty
body:
Attending our 12 week scan an anomaly was picked up by the sonographer. Immediately they referred us to the Fetal Medicine Team at Kirkcaldy and we were seen the same afternoon, and subsequently referred to the team at Edinburgh Royal Infirmary. What I can only describe as a nightmare situation finding our baby had a genetic condition that meant they were unlikely to survive to term we had the awful decision to make with the support of the Fetal Medicine team at Kirkcaldy.  
We were admitted to the maternity ward the following weekend. We can not thank enough all those who cared for us from the midwives and sonographer at Dunfermline, Fetal Medicine Teams at Kirkcaldy and Edinburgh and the midwives on the maternity ward at Kirkcaldy. During a time of uncertainty and constant change with Covid 19 we were treated timely with care and compassion from everyone and can not fault the professionalism of staff. It allowed us get through an awful time in our lives with the quality of care we received. Thank you.

title: Drug delivery
body: Unable to contact them. Cost a lot not getting connected. Was trying to get my drugs delivery date. They are overdue. This is the second time this has happened. First time they tried to blame me then my surgery. When at last I received my drugs I was treated as a new patient.

title: Very Good Service
body: very good, highly attentive and have never had any complaints.

title: Great patient care and compassion
body: I feel compelled to leave a review for this practice as in today’s world it was refreshing to experience true patient care first hand as I dealt with my father health matters. The staff are attentive and knowledgable as well as compassionate and proactive. The staff members who assisted me with this matter clearly has a true vocation of care and I can not praise her highly enough, she had an existing awareness of who my father is and treated him with respect and dignity, going above and beyond to assure both myself and my dad. I really can not say thank you enough for all your help and support.

author: Confused and saddened
title: Treatment of a dementia patient (my mum) with covid 19
body:
My mum was admitted to gri in March . She has dementia and became unwell a couple of days before with rather vague symptoms . She was off her food / drowsy / nil liquids etc , paramedics attended ( fabulous guys who put her at ease ) . They explained due to the current pandemic I could not be with her through her assessment however they would explain to the nursing staff that it was desirable I was present to answer questions she cannot answer herself , this did not happen and indeed my mother was left on her own for five hours on a trolley while I sat in a separate waiting area patiently waiting on an update .  
Eventually I approached reception to be told the day staff had not informed the night staff I was there!!!! I was ( five hours later allowed to be with her ) she was then transferred to a medical receiving ward . At no point did any of the staff wear protective equipment .  
The next day I telephoned to be told she had pneumonia . She was subsequently tested for covid 19 and tested positive . At no point did anyone suspect this and no personal protection equipment was worn by any staff . My mum was treated promptly and efficiently by the staff in ward 50 ( the second ward and third department of her 24 hr visit ) . I was then allowed a one off visit wearing said PPE . During this visit staff cane round with the ‘tea trolley’ and one member of staff kindly made mum tea . She wore no gloves / mask and kindly fixed mums oxygen ( nostrils ) then proceeded to go to the next room . A member of the medical team spoke to me re DNR .  
Mum improved and the following day happily continued to improve , sadly in isolation. You can only imagine how difficult this would be for her . The following day I was informed she was being moved to ward 7 . A lovely member of the medical team phoned me to explain what was happening . Due to the fact she was covid positive you will be aware myself and my family are currently in isolation for 14 days . I explained this and this was met with reassurance due to her dementia she would be looked after until able to be sent home .  
Sadly from that moment this has not been the case . She was subsequently moved to ward 46 having had one negative result for covid and then one positive . I was informed this was the best place for her .. . She remained there through Monday , I assumed until discharge . Sadly on tues evening less than 48 hrs in this dedicated ward I was phoned at 9pm to be told she was being moved again to ward 62 that evening . No explanation was given other than we need the beds and we are more of a receiving ward . I ask the question why move an80 yr old woman with dementia there in the first place ?  
She is now being moved to her fourth ward and sixth room in her ten day stay . No visitors ( I understand the difficult time we are all having ) The ward cannot tell me which consultant she will be under . She is by now agitated , confused and lost . Do you consider this fair and person centred care of an 80 yr old patient with dementia and covid .  
She will be once again lost and agitated and confused. She will also be under another medical team . I am baffled and as a staff member of GG and C frankly very saddened .  
I would appreciate a response

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2021)
Office of Ken Macintosh, MSP for West of Scotland

title: Very unprofessional
body: I am not a person to leave reviews but this time I actually think is needed. I suffer from severe depression and anxiety for a long time ( couple of years ) and 2 years ago my friend helped me understand that i need help , so GP made a referral for me to Crombie house! I’ve been seen ( once )  and put on medication and after that i haven’t been seen again , I struggled a lot and no one even carried about my problems even if i was calling every day and ask for help ! In aug 2019 i found out i am pregnant and my mental health got worse and worse , my gp changed my medication and referred me again to Crombie House ! I had no appointments from august till now in march ! My Midewife been extremely worried for me and called every day in my name , gp as well they where very worried contacted them again , health visitor as well was worried and contact them and nothing , i have not been seen for 6 months by no one from Crombie house even if so many requests have been made by so many people that they where truly worried about me ! On 24 march i had an appointment made from 5 months ago (  i was on “ emergency list “ all this time apparantly) and now with Corona virus , they contact me and told me that appointment will be by phone , that was 1 week ago ! I waited all day for that phone call that never happen , I’ve called Crombie house and they said “ we sorry dr will call you “ today is 31 march and no one still haven’t called me ! I waited for this appointment 6 MONTHS , 6 longgg months that i struggle so much that only i know ! I was referred to them from beginning of my pregnancy and now i have only 5 weeks left till my delivery! This is outrageous and so unprofessional! I wish i was living in a bigger city to have more support as this “ clinic “ is an absolute joke and they do not do there job in any way ! I am upset , depressed, stressed , with my anxiety lever over the roof and all I received when i asked for help was a big NOTHING! Very disappointed! Shame on you Crombie house !

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Renemac
title: My infant feeding support worker
body:
I first met my infant feeding support worker at anti natal classes she took. This was my 4th baby and I had breastfed my older three but I learned so much that I didn't know about breastfeeding from Lana at this class. Lana made me feel so at ease and look forward to labour and delivery, instead of feeling worried and anxious. Lana taught me breathing and relaxation techniques that I'm still using now. These techniques helped so much in pregnancy and labour.  
I have brittle asthma and my pregnancy and labour/delivery was high risk but I felt much more relaxed and in control using the techniques and strategies that Lana taught me. Everything was explained clearly and with such reassuring calm that I looked forward to them classes so much! If I missed anything Lana always took the time to make sure I knew and understood what I missed, always going the extra mile with all of us at the class.  
After my son was born Lana was in touch with me. She must spend hours personally getting to know every new mother but she is there to support everyone whenever she is needed. My baby had a tongue tie which Lana helped my midwife refer. He had this cut at a week old. Then he developed thrush. I took him to the doctors twice in two weeks, each time with different treatment. Nothing was working. It was Lana that told me what treatment he needed, what we both needed. I went back to the doctors and was prescribed the correct treatment. The doctor asked me to get in touch with Lana to ask what dose I should be taking and how often. This was 5.30 on a Friday night. I messaged lana and she replied with the dose /frequency. After a couple of days we were both so much better and enjoying feeding. Such a shame it took three weeks to get the right treatment but without Lana we wouldn't have even got it then. She is a legend. The fact the GP refers back to get says it all. Any time I've had an issue, Lana has been on hand every on the phone or she'll pop round. From boobing to pooping, I wouldn't have felt so comfortable or confident without Lana's support and I certainly wouldn't still be feeling myself 6 months later. She helped us with the tongue tie, thrush, poor latch and reflux. Poor baba did not have it easy. I would have given up without Lana. She worked with us both to help with all his wee issues and keep feeding going. Lana also runs a feeding support group that we go to. This is open to anyone and we are welcome to come and go as we can. Lana is always so welcoming and makes time for everyone there. She always offers you a cuppa and a treat and has a chat. Everyone there is very friendly but that's because Lana makes you all feel so welcome and relaxed. When my baby was first born lana was weighing the babies at the group. She would only do this is you had your red book so she would record it. This was excellent as seeing the health visitor is extremely tricky. (There is a health visitor clinic once a month for a couple of hours but guaranteed that is when your in laws call round or you've been up all night or car is in the garage or something always happens making it impossible to get to that window to get the baby weighed. I have only once made it in 6 months!) I am very lucky that the health visitor has came for a home visit and I had my baby weighed three times. I know several other mums who never had their babies weighed after hand over from the midwife. It was a brilliant service that Lana offered weighing the babies. Such a shame she can't do it any more. It must have really helped the health visitors too as without this service loads of babies were never getting weighed at all. Not only could the mums keep track of their babies weight but if there was any concerns then this could be flagged up. I'd love to see Lana weighing the babies at the group again. I'd love to know how heavy my wee toot is now! Lana is you read this thank you so much for everything. Please keep up the amazing work you do, we couldn't do it without you 💖. Only one thing, bring back your scales 😄.

author: Eva G
title: They failed to diagnose a basic food poison
body:
I was admitted to hospital after what I thought was a flare up of ulcerative colitis, as I had returned from holiday the doctors thought I had picked up a bacteria, they put me in a side room, and anyone coming into see me had to wear protective clothing.  
My blood was taken every 6 hours to see what bacteria would grow, everyday I got my medication changed, the nurse in charge, I can't remember their name, was adamant they wanted my bed back for some one that needed it more, I could hear them say I wouldn't be staying, they needed that room and didn't care - like I wanted to be there??  
The nurse got their way and I was sent home after 5 days in hospital, following day I was readmitted for the same symptoms, there was no beds so I was booked into toxicology ward, the ward where over doses and mental health patients are kept in a locked room. Following day the gastroenlogy doctors came to see me, they now felt it was my ulcerative colitis rather than a bacteria, they sent me home with medication, for 3 weeks I got more and more ill, I handed a stool sample into my GP who confirmed I had salmonella! And had had it for 6 weeks, which all the doctors at the royal had failed to diagnose,  
Following week I was sent to have a colonoscopy, the doctor performing the procedure asked why I was on so much medication, I informed him I had salmonella - he hadn't been informed - he told me he would puncture my insides with anything going inside them given how inflamed they would be.  
I lost 15% of my body weight. 2 Stone, my BMI is now 17 and all my muscles have wasted away  
Five months since I first got sick I am still unwell with reactive arthritis in my hips caused by the salmonella, my ulcerative colitis is constantly inflamed, I can't do basic tasks due to the lack of muscle I now have and I am not back at work full time  
I was under the hospitals care for 3 weeks and they failed to diagnose a basic food poison that I had been displaying all the symptoms of and I was in the correct gastroenterology ward  
Perhaps if the nurse wasn't so adamant I was to leave I would have been given the care I deserved and needed  
The Royal infirmary couldn't protect me

author: liseday
title: My son's illness
body: My son, who was a young very fit man, developed acute Crohns. After suffering first from Ulcerative colitis, it turned into Crohns. Unfortunately just as we went into lockdown because of Covid19 his conditioned worsened and he needed a stoma, bypassing his big colon. Surgery went well but he came home after only two days, because of the danger of the virus. My daughter-in-law and I tried to give him the level of care required but because he was so nauseous and had deep painful hiccups for days on end it was very difficult. He was scared of eating. Last night he collapsed and we called an ambulance. They arrived in 15 minutes and showed such professionalism, care and compassion. Now he is getting his stoma unblocked and being hydrated. WE owe a great debt to the NHS and especially the ambulance crew and paramedics. Grateful.

readBy.name: Royal Surrey County Hospital NHS Foundation Trust
South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust

author: K-B-S
title: Painful injection at home
body: Last week I did my usual MS injection. It was unusually painful. After that my thigh became hurtful whenever I touched it. I called my MS nurse (Bhawani) to ask about the whole situation - why this happened and what I can do about it. She explained everything and reassured me.

author: kpat
title: Daughter and bronchiolitis
body: At the end of October 2018 me and my husband noticed our 1 year olds breathing had started to change, she had a temperature and did not want to move or eat. I phoned 111 and explained what was going on, I couldn't have asked for nicer, more efficient advisor on the other end of the phone. She sent an ambulance for my daughter straight away and she was rushed to hospital. It turned out my daughter had bronchiolitis and wasn't getting enough oxygen. We stayed in hospital on an isolation ward for 1 week until she could keep her oxygen levels up by herself. I will forever be grateful to the nhs 111 health advisor who made the decision to call an ambulance. And to all the doctors and nurses who helped her during that week.

readBy.name: South East Coast Ambulance Service NHS Foundation Trust

author: Muffin man
title: The nurses there have so much time for you
body:
I was diagnosed with stage 3 breast cancer in 2019,the care I have received was excellent,the chemo ward ladies 310 have so much time for everybody ,my oncologist was brilliant ,said it how it was ,explained everything to me ,mr mcgoldrick.my breast cancer nurse Shona ,kept me goin she is my angel , all the breast nurses were always nice an patient, my surgeon mr Nadeem was wonderful,. Ward 208 the nurses there have so much time for you .ward 309, one Senior nurse told me I would only need paracetamol for the pain of having my breast removed,?.  
If only she knew ,was not happy with that comment.overall all I can say I will never forget the treatment I had from Ari they saved my life ,I will always be eternally grateful.

author: Workingmummyof3
title: They took away his worries about hospital
body:
Our son was recently admitted to Paediatric Ward 19 then through to Ward 20 at University Hospital Wishaw via out of hours. He had appendicitis and was treated with outstanding care throughout.  
As parents we were clearly worried about our son, however all staff from out of hours Doctor, Nurses & Doctors in Wards 19 & 20, Anesthetist, Surgeon and Nurses within the operating theatre gave care which we cannot thank them enough for. Everything was explained to us whilst we were also asked if we understood or had any questions. Our son was able to tell them when worried or scared and all who were involved gave him explanations he could understand and reassurances that everything happening was OK.  
Our son also has Autism and his needs were always taken into consideration even the anaesthetist asked what would make this easiest for our child to understand and she spoke to him direct in a way he could relate. We stayed for 2 nights, and can only speak highly of the paediatric team. Simple things like the food options for meals, the playroom when fit enough after surgery and just the smiles on the nurses faces has made our son have nice memories of his short stay in hospital which have helped him forget about the pain and fear he had whilst there. He says they took away his worries about hospital but especially Nurse Jackie in ward 20. Jackie cared for him the day of his surgery prior to theatre and when he returned to the ward. As well as care, she was helping with his dressings when one came off, calming him down with us when he got anxious and encouraging him. Thank you Jackie and everyone involved.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: gymthing
title: Treatment options.
body: After having an anxiety/depressive episode, I was urgently referred to Ealing CATT team by my GP, dealing with psychiatrist Dr. Sufraz. He helped me by suggesting viable talking and medicine options with me. So going forward, hopefully these will prove effective in helping me.

author: Johnson100
title: Treliske adult insulin pump therapy
body:
I moved to Cornwall using an insulin pump with NHS funding initiated by another CCG area. I was given no choice of where I could be treated but was told I could only attend the Royal Cornwall Hospital, RCHT (Treliske), for an insulin pump clinic. Here I would have to be reviewed in order to continue receiving NHS funding for my treatment, which also at Treliske unusually includes a compulsory "patient contract".  
What followed was a string of appointments issued then cancelled by the hospital within a few weeks of each being issued, this continued for over 6 months. In the mean time, as I had not received one appointment that the hospital would keep, my life saving medical supplies were running out. Various local NHS medical staff and myself attempted to speak with specialist staff there for approx 10 weeks, leaving messages, sending emails and formal letters, but no-one at Treliske helped, they did not communicate with either me as a patient, my GP's or any community based NHS staff. At this point I gave in and after much NHS fighting I managed to organize myself an appointment in Devon. It appears to me that the adult insulin pump clinic at Treliske operates to block adult patients from accessing insulin pump therapy. I think they should feel ashamed at how this hospital treated me as an adult type 1 diabetic patient on insulin pumps, and I believe they really need to change their attitude, be retrained or should be closed down. I had contacted complaints team, but they didn't get back to me. The pump team clearly knew that this problem existed but did not act on it. It's good to see a now publicly available RCHT adult insulin pump service pathway document, but sadly it doesn't include any information on service accessibility or had any patient input, lots of patients being made to jump through hoops but no commitment or accountability from clinical staff or managers - if RCHT would like some help with this please contact me. Overall my experience conclusion in attempting to receive pump therapy at RCHT is I will avoid using this hospital at all costs in future.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2022)
Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Johnson100
title: Diabetes Specialist Nurse in Outpatients
body:
I've now had a couple of face to face appointments and numerous telephone appointments with the diabetes specialist nursing service in outpatients and have to say they are fantastic!  
Their clinics rarely run late, are very focused on problem solving diabetes issues while still being friendly, helpful and generally supportive. I love their "can do" attitude and they always make time to help if needed, can't ask for more!

author: Johnson100
title: Diabetes clinic outpatient appointment
body:
I attended an outpatient clinic appointment for insulin pump therapy patients, I expected it to have a focus on pump therapy and its consequences, such as discussions of blood glucose levels, hypos, hypers, HbA1c blood test result etc, but most of appointment was very vague and non-specific, no recommendations were made for any changes in pump treatment or monitoring, as such I felt it was a waste of their time and mine.  
I felt that the whole appointment was formula based as a box ticking exercise with little to no interest in my individual situation, my concerns or preferences. The appointment ended somewhat abruptly when I refused to discuss taking medications that had no influence on my blood glucose levels and the same ones I had previously refused to take.  
I left very unhappy and upset for the second time by a consultant clinic appointment, leaving in tears from my appointment where I felt I was being harassed and bullied with no consideration or respect was given to my choice of treatment, my opinion or my clinical decisions. Overall I felt that the consultant was being driven by a box ticking process with no concern for the individual, patient rights or the consent.  
At the appointment there were 3 staff members in the appointment room with me, but no-one had asked if I was ok with this. Including one doctor that was just apparently observing, it made me feel very uncomfortable, especially when they smirked at me as I was disagreeing with the consultant.  
It's a shame as it could be a really good clinic and much more accessible than most others in the south west, but sadly too many assumptions are made about patients and no respect is given to type 1 patients who ironically deliver their own care 100% of the time, it's so important for a consultant to work with a patient not to attempt to dictate treatment to them- this ruins lives. I really hope some productive changes can be made.

author: Johnson100
title: practice nurse appointment
body:
I had an appointment with a practice for a B12 injection, given that the Corona virus had started to spread significantly when this appointment was due I wasn't sure if they would still see me.  
I received a phone call from nurse in advance to reassure me that they would still see me for this appointment and were taking measures to ensure that the waiting area would be safe even for higher risk patients such as me.  
I only had to wait a couple of minutes before the appointment, it went well, quick and painless, she organised me a further appointment for the future. A friendly helpful reassuring service.

author: Tobyblue
title: Ear deafness due to excessive wax
body:
I was recently seen at out of hours as I had severe deafness and ear pain. I was instructed to continue olive oil drops as my ears had lots of wax, then to hold a hot shower hose to flush out wax also to buy a self ear syringe bulb. However this has caused me to get otitis externa also known as swimmer's ear.  
I saw my own gp who just happens to be specialised in microsuction and ears, who said you should never put water in the ears as this can cause infection. Luckily I didn't do it to both ears only the one that is now infected. I feel that staff must be informed never to suggest putting water in the ears.  
I was also seen by another staff member who was very good and helpful.

links.id: upset as advice given has caused infection

author: Emmrd63
title: Pay rise deserved
body: Lucy did a really good job for me and helped me, can you give Lucy a pay rise for me, she worked really hard for me. They have now moved me, and I would like you to thank her for me, she deserves a pay rise

title: Lack of communication- appointment cancelled on…
body: I received numerous confirmations of the appointment, the last being one day prior to my appointment. I followed the preparation and had the day booked off work in order to attend. On arrival I was told that all of the appointments had been cancelled. Considering not being informed of any cancellation, I still attended after the confirmation was received not even 24 hours previously. I have unnecessarily attended which has not only put myself at risk by leaving the house but also my family for no reason. A simple phone call from the clinic to cancel wouldn’t go a miss. I understand that this is a very busy time for healthcare, however cancelling appointments should be high priority to ensure that patients don’t unnecessarily leave their homes only to be told on arrival and in the waiting room that theirs was cancelled.

title: Excellent, efficient and helpful surgery
body:
We, two adults and two young children, have been registered with this practice for the last three years, and we have always received excellent care. The doctors listen and consider each case carefully. They are helpful and efficient and have at times gone above and beyond for us. We've had to face some difficult circumstances in the past few years, and our GP was always there for us: she knew the whole family and remembered our situation every time we saw her. 
The practise staff are welcoming and accommodating to our needs. The surgery is centrally located, is always spotless, has good waiting rooms and facilities.

title: Excellent service
body:
During this unprecedented time, have been delighted with the service from the reception staff and Doctors I have received in the last few weeks.

A huge thanks to all the wonderful NHS staff.

title: Awful place
body:
I would only attend in an absolutely life or death situation, and even then, give it careful consideration.

why?????

Most of the receptionists are rude, obnoxious and generally unhelpful. If you are in pain, well - that's unlucky because they have absolutely written in stone policies.

Appointments are difficult to get, and when I did get to see a doctor about 1 thing & I asked him about something else, he refused YES, refused to talk about it sating "I would have to examine you." So, I had to get a second appointment and waste more of his and my time, when he could have sorted it in 60 seconds on my 1st appointment.

Turns out that he got the diagnosis completely wrong. Well, to be honest, he did say "I don't know what's wrong with your shoulder."

I asked for a referral to a specialist & I was told to look online and find someone myself.

Pain relief was issued to me by another her doctor, and in fact this medicine was completely wrong for my condition.

I was shouted at by one receptionist and accused of being rude when I asked that as my prescription was now 3 days late, what am. supposed to do if I feel very unwell in the middle of the night? Should I all an ambulance? Apparently, this constitutes rude behaviour on my part, and I was expected to apologise for my conduct.

Shameful.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: One of the best
body: It's quite daunting being under a certain age and staying in a care home I was sent to rowthorne after being discharged from hospital everyone has an opinion about some homes being smelly etc I know I did I arrived late and staff were very kind and polite it didn't smell at all bye the next day I found staff really friendly and professional one of my many issues I was under weight that was over a week ago I wouldn't say I have that issue now they cater for every need from being vegan diabetic and celiac and if they don't have what you require they will get it for you nothing is too much trouble and also dealing with things once your home everything is in place everyone of them are lovely the residents are treated with dignity and respect I can honestly say I don't want to go home I've made some lovely friends and would not hesitate in an instant to recommend rowthorne to anyone                Well done ladies all of you ❤️

title: Wonderful care
body: I attended maternity assessment during the night on 1st April due to concerns regarding my baby’s movements. I was extremely well cared for by my midwife and other staff, I was seen very quickly, I was not rushed, everything was explained clearly and I left feeling extremely reassured. During this time of immense strain on the NHS I was extremely appreciative of the care I received and feel very lucky to be a patient of Queens. I will look forward to the birth of my baby in a week or so in complete confidence that I will be in the best hands. Every time I have attended Queens in recent years (various depts) the service has been exceptional. Many many thanks and please know your care and effort does not go unnoticed.

title: Poor Service
body: Not happy. I have been messed about and diagnosed badly here for various health issues I've experienced. Prescriptions not ready on time has happened on more than one occasion also. The main GP at the practice is not good at listening, quite bombastic in attitude and dismissive of patients thoughts about their own health conditions. Has not been very helpful towards me on several occasions over the years. I will seek to find a new GP.

title: Very helpful and easy to access service
body: I received very good counselling in this really down to earth practice. Everybody I met was kind and emphatic and I cannot thank enough my counsellor for helping and supporting me at a very difficult point in my life. He was very professional and capable and thought me very useful coping strategies that I will continue to apply in everyday's life and no doubt in the future when I will face other issues. I cannot recommend this service enough, it feels like it has changed my life. It is true that one never stops to learn.

readBy.name: South London and Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust

title: What an amazing clean welcoming practice!
body:
What can I say, I’ve had such welcoming and happy experience here the girls are all amazing they made me laugh from going in to coming out! 
It was such clean and happy place so welcoming

title: Love the callback system
body: In the last year I have had to contact the surgery several times regarding a medical problem.  I cannot praise the new callback system too highly.  I booked a phone call online using the Patient Access app on my phone.  The doctor called at the requested time and, after a brief chat, I was given very good advice.  When needed, I got a face-to-face appointment the same day.  I don't think you can ask for a better service.

title: The worst GP ever.
body:
No wonder it was stated as one of worst gp in south London.
The receptionist lack professionalism, very disgusting as they don't know how to talk to people. They dont realise they get paid from people's hard earned money. All them need to sacked or least give them training. They need to realise people who come to gp have different illnesses so they need to handle them with care.

The doctor's are ok. They always change, because of that they dont have a connection with the patient. Always have visitors doctor who are useless.

The manager, well dont know if their is one there. No interaction between receptionist. If the manager was more responsible the receptionist would have acted better to patient.

title: A beakon of light in these Unpresedented times
body: Even though it’s a very difficult time for the NHS this service has been providing exceptional service. I want to say a huge thank you to the man who works on reception, he’s very calm and the most helpful person I’ve spoke to, really goes out of his way to help you sort out your problems, with a very calming voice, it’s people like this that make the NHS such a good service.

title: Unbelievable service and team of doctors and…
body: We have been with Thurleigh Road for many years and can never move out of their catchment area.  They provide such an exceptionally good and supportive service, always have, have a phenomenal team of doctors, nurses and admin/support staff.  They have supported my family through some very tough times and never cease to impress me.  Anyone able to register with them should consider themselves incredibly fortunate!

title: GREAT PRACTISE
body:
Helpful receptionists and nurses.

Very professional and caring Doctors

We have been with this surgery for 30 years .

Always get a very quick appointment.

We appreciate you .

Michael ,Urszula,Alexander  Cicale

title: Great practice
body:
Went for routine appointment. Good communication 
Social distancing in place 
Friendly helpful lady on front door letting people in explaining things.
Good organisation in this difficult time in all areas

title: Excellent Practice
body: I am blessed to be so lucky to be under the care of Burnt Ash Surgery.  I cannot praise the doctors and nurses high enough for their care, kindness and understanding.  Sadly my Parents aren't here anymore, but the love, care and help they received from everyone at the Practice is outstanding.  We couldn't ask for better.  This is also for the reception staff too.  Thank you.

title: Outstanding Practice
body:
Honestly the care, attention and professionalism of the staff in this surgery is a credit to the NHS. At an exceptionally busy time I was treated with patience, promptness and efficiency. 
The reception staff are brilliant and the online booking system user friendly. 
Thank you to all of the team at Balham Park Surgery, I'm very proud to be registered with you and your unwavering friendly support in the community.

title: Incredible Service
body: Excellent Surgery. Always been impressed with Langley House Surgery since we registered in Aug 2018. I'm even more impressed now. I rang yesterday morning, got a telephone appt today with my choice of GP. He rang before 9am. I collected my sick certificate by 10 and my prescription from Boots straight after. The staff at the surgery were friendly and calm during what must be an exceptionally busy time. Top notch and an incredible service during a challenging time.

title: Review not published
body: Following surgery left a generally positive review, but critical of Phoenix ward, cleaning and cateting. Never published

title: Phone blunder
body:
Had a phone consultation with one of the doctors. That was ver much appreciated. I am known by most members of staff as i also work for a nearby GP surgery but I happen to be a patient at this practice.
At the end of the phone call the Dr did not put the phone down properly and i assumed i was on hold. I could hear one of the reception staff who i spoke to earlier that morning say " she works at a gp surgery, so she should know better".

This is just wrong. I am a patient just like anyone else. Whether i work at a GP surgery or not is irrelevant. How embarrassing this will be for the surgery.  

Put yourself in the patient's shoes. Its a bad time for everyone but a patronising and dismissive attitude from that member of staff will only stress patients more. Veru upsetting.

title: MRI scan
body: The service in the medical imaging department was very good although a short wait was expected. It was clean and comfortable and the staff were all nice and friendly. I would be happy to go back there again if needed/

readBy.name: East Kent Hospitals University NHS Foundation Trust

title: Stunning team support for me and my husband
body: I honestly could not have had a better experience with the whole practice team. We are not frequent users of services but my husband has been really ill and honestly there has not been one poor experience from any of the gps or reception team. We have been included in the thinking and next steps and our opinion and thoughts have been welcomed. Thank you for helping us through this tough time

title: Ignorant and hostile environment
body:
Rapid Access Chest Pain Clinic:

Initially, I did not want to leave any feedback because I did not want the outcome of the appointment to affect any future care from this clinic. 

Invited to a hostile environment with one very aggressive nurse taking charge. The other nurse sat away, and tried to distance herself (and her opinions) as the first nurse lashed out. The nurse did not seem to have read the notes and had already made presumptions on several areas, including ethnicity (ethnicity is not always determined by place of birth). The first nurse kept pushing comparisons of two different ethnic backgrounds and suggested advice mainly centered around her own lifestyle options (eg. cycling). The lack of tact, nurture and communication skills from the nurse made the whole process uncomfortable from beginning to end. 

I'd like to think it was a 'one off' incident, however the second nurse's behaviour seemed to suggest otherwise.

title: Excellent practice
body: Very professional and caring, can call and get advice from very friendly receptionists and the doctors are extremely helpful.

title: Rude receptionist.
body: Have to agree with previous reviews, practice itself is OK, it's just a shame the people on reception are always abrupt whenever I go in.

title: amazing service
body: the staff are always very kind and as helpful as they are able to be. the hours are workable around my university schedule, so i am always able to visit if i need to.

title: Telephone triage
body: I would like to thank our Dr for his telephone triage consultation. I was able to explain my concerns regarding my 89 father and he was able to give advice and send a prescription to our chemist for today. Very much appreciated. My grateful thanks to all NHS staff. Stay safe

title: Excellent service
body: I have always received first class service and treatment from every member of this practice... from the reception team to the nurses and doctors. Thank you.

title: A practice that prioritises
body:
Recently whilst waiting in reception and wondering if I'd have to wait long enough to get a cup of coffee,  I remembered something my father used to say.  It's the sign of a good health professional if they're running late because you know that if you genuinely need extra time, they'll do their best to give it.  I thought of how, over the decades I have been a patient there, the members of this team, both clinical and administrative,  have kept me and so many others alive and as well as we can be, speeding through the straightforward things and spending longer when needed.

I'm amazed how well the admin staff cope with impatient patients who consider being seen on the dot of their appointment time as more important than seeing a doctor who's caring enough to spend extra time with patients when they need it.  Why hassle the staff on reception?  Do those patients expect them to have a crystal ball?   

Mind you, it is easy for us (me included) to develop high expectations of a practice with high standards!

author: El-17
title: My care on the stroke ward at pilgrim hospital
body: I am only 30 years old and I had no movement on my left side of my face. I was so scared with what had happened. All staff on that ward was brilliant and so informative. The way that they speak and treat patients is incredible. As I wasn’t allowed any visitors, nurses even came to talk to me to keep me company every now and then. They are all amazing people and true hero’s. I wanted to thank them for looking after me and for doing a great job.

author: Speedyman
title: I had not slept properly for many years
body: I was becoming physically ill as a result of our son's life style. As a result of our son (now 32 years old) descending into a life of drugs, gambling, petty crime and homelessness, after many interventions emotionally and financially, I had not slept properly for many years and was finally becoming physically ill and regularly not being fit to attend work. I had become heavily dependant on caffeine to function and pressure from the extended family added a negative effect to the situation. The service was helpful in moving forward, the counsellor was fantastic.

author: Bmac
title: Extremely thoughtful and professional staff
body: Had heart palpitations and was rushed into Lincoln. From the paramedics, to consultants the whole staff were caring, considerate and kind making my stay bearable under difficult circumstances. The nurses were extremely thoughtful and professional in every way looking after me and other patients with compassion. The support staff where also friendly and polite, however hopefully I won't have to book a second visit. Amazing People.

author: Dionnex
title: I felt listened to
body:
A few weeks ago I ended up being sent to the Surgical Assessment Unit at the Western General Hospital. My GP who was very good had me sent up to the hospital to be seen due to being unable to pass urine. I was seen to quite quickly by a nurse called Samantha who was so kind.  
The nursing staff went above and beyond when I was in the unit they would come and check in on me regularly to check I was ok and if I needed anything. They had to bleep the urology doctors 3 times but had no response but the nurses kept trying as they knew how sore I was and wanted to get a plan sorted. The doctor I saw was good he listened to what had been happening health wise and discussed what they could do to help. I was then looked after by the night shift staff and again they were really good. Amanda (I think her name was) came in introduced herself and told me she was going to be putting a catheter in I’d never had one put in before and was a bit nervous but Amanda kept making sure I was ok throughout and briefly explained the catheter pack I’d take home with me and who to contact if I had any issues.  
I’m not sure if I got the names of the staff correct but if you can find out and pass on my thanks and that they are doing a great job especially with things being difficult due to Covid-19.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

author: Lsdtm
title: I could not have wished for greater care
body: I went to Pilgrim Hospital as I was showing some of the signs that suggest I had, had a stroke. On presentation was given priority over one other patient in the waiting room to go to the triage staff. She took her time and reassured me throughout the process and took me to the treatment room. Within minutes I had put on the monitors, the consultant and sister from the stroke ward were directing the treatment and asking questions about what had happened. Within 5 or six minutes I was given medication directly into my vein and to reduce my severely high blood pressure. Within a further 5 minutes taken for a CT scan and taken directly from their to the stroke ward. In these desperate times with the Coronavirus I could not have wished for or received greater care from all the staff I came into contact with during my stay. I having nothing but very high praise for everyone who had a hand in my care and I would like you to pass on my sincere thanks to everyone concerned over the two days. Thank you very much for the outstanding way you cared for me.

author: Laurel
title: I will never forget them
body:
The staff at derby hospital radiotherapy unit are fantastic, every part of my treatment was explained in detail at the beginning and after 2 weeks in I feel like they are good friends, we have a laugh about something every day which makes my 50 mile round journey every day an absolute breeze, absolutely wonderful people who bring a smile to their patients who are going through a tough time, I will never forget them x  
Thank you from the bottom of my heart xx

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: Life saving
body: I went to my GP on 23 March and was diagnosed with a very low heart rate I arrived at Barnet Hospital at about 10.30am and at 3.30 in the afternoon i was having a pacemaker fitted I woke up from the operation was given dinner and at 8.00 pm I was discharged i would say there is, almost nowhere else on earth that this could happen and would if i could would like to thank individually everyone who helped me that day it was life changing and life saving and i cant thankyou enough. In light of this is there anything barnet hospital needs that individuals coyld provide like on an amazon wish list let me know

readBy.name: Royal Free London NHS Foundation Trust

title: Disrespectful Doctor
body:
Had an appointment over the phone with a Dr at this practice and they didn’t understand where on my body I was experiencing pain even though I repeated 6 times. Dr then repeatedly asked if I had swelling to which I replied no 5 times. Spoke to me like I’m a child when I’m a man in my 60s and I was left out of breath after having to continuously explain my problem, which I was doing very clearly. This Dr expected me to finish sentences at the end of the call as if I were being tested me on a lesson they had just given me. This Dr also rather disrespectfully asked me if I was responsible enough to collect my tablets from the pharmacy and take them. 

Doctor done all of this whilst voice was raised, in an extremely condescending and patronising manner.

author: Bebe17
title: Unsupportive post-birth care.
body:
I had an emergency C-section with my first child and therefore was admitted to Wheal Fortune Ward for three days.  
I would firstly like to qualify that certain members of staff were polite, kind and compassionate and delivered appropriate and adequate care. I do not wish to tarnish all the staff with the same brush. My complaint relates to two individual members of staff who were "looking after me" on a night shift.  
Their introduction was abrupt and rude and they immediately made it clear that their approach was that I would do things their way. Their care was not patient centred and was very dominant. I was experiencing a lot of pain post surgery and was also experiencing shoulder and arm muscle spasms making it very difficult to hold and feed my baby.  
The previous midwife had organised regular strong analgesia for me and told me to inform the night staff that I would require this hourly. I let the two new staff members know who completely dismissed my request, saying that they wouldn't jump straight to that and that I could just have ibuprofen. I explained that was not sufficient but my concerns were ignored. I then explained that without the pain relief, I would therefore need help to pick up and feed the baby - as even getting in and out of bed was difficult. The response from one member of staff was that they were not going to be at home with me, and told me that I would have to manage by myself.  
During this introduction I felt intimidated by the two people standing at the end of the bed, who were ignoring all I was saying and making it very clear I should pipe down and get on with it on my own. I felt ganged up on and bullied. My heart sank realising how difficult the night ahead was clearly going to be and my pain began to increase due to being denied the pain relief. Subsequently my arm went into spasm causing me great distress. One staff member physically tried to manhandle me to the bathroom, saying I needed to empty my bladder as I had been previously catheterised and ignored the pain and distress I was in. I sat on the edge of the bed, trying to explain I could not move and in a lot of pain and they just huffed and told me to go back to bed and tried to get me to lie down, again ignoring my distress. They then repeatedly criticised me throughout the night when I struggled to feed my baby every three hours, yet offering no help and continuing to ignore my exhaustion and pain levels. They also told me off for failing to complete a feeding chart, when I had never been given one or told to use one by anybody.  
They asked another patient if they were ok in the next bay, and when they said they were, loudly said something like 'well at least someone is doing well and managing fine' I felt as if to highlight that I was a troublemaker.  
I was continually promised that someone was coming to assess my baby's tongue tie throughout my stay but they never did, despite my repeated requests to multiple staff members. In the meantime, I had to unnecessarily struggle to breastfeed my baby and have the tongue tie cut post-discharge. I found this unsatisfactory when the baby's tongue tie was identified immediately following birth, yet three days later by the time of my discharge, no action had been taken.  
I was close to discharging myself as I felt completely unsupported, bullied and unnecessarily criticised. I felt I could better care for my baby at home which says a lot about the lack of care I received that night. I was vulnerable, in a lot of pain and felt completely alone and frightened. It was a very negative experience.  
I was shocked at the way I was treated as a patient.

readBy.name: Plymouth University Health and Human Sciences students, 2018

title: Thank you Ward F9
body: My dad is in ward F9 at the moment and I’m unable to visit him due to isolation. Thank you for looking after him and when I called today reassuring me that when he is released from hospital he’ll be given help from either carers or a rehabilitation temporary accommodation until he’s on his feet. With these uncertain times I really really appreciate everything you are doing.

title: Unfortunately disappointing.
body:
The online system is fine if you have something that you think can wait up to a fortnight, but anything else means waiting in a phone queue, sometimes anywhere up to an hour.

I've tried the DoctorLink app. It recommended I see someone within a day. After 2 days with no response at all (not even a holding email saying the surgery was extremely busy) I ended up ringing the surgery.

I've had an appointment letter sent to me and when I arrived at the surgery there was no appointment. This is fine if you're retired but I work and have to take time off to get to the surgery.

I've had one receptionist be unapologetically rude to my face when they didn't want to help.

When I've had appointments booked they often start late - usually only 5-10 minutes late, but sometimes up to 3/4 hour after the scheduled appointment was due.

I've had one GP say they will make an appointment for me with the hospital and after a three week wait for a letter its transpired that hadn't been done, leading to further delays getting the hospital appointment.

I've also had distinctly unsympathetic responses from some members of staff in relation to things I've sought help for. I appreciate that not every medical complaint requires a massive investigation, I appreciate doctors, nurses and receptionists are often extremely busy, and I appreciate everyone has off days but a show of at least some sympathy goes a long way.

I find it disappointing to say that as a result of numerous small things like those listed above I have lost faith in this practice and the level of care it offers. I often feel like I'm fighting an uphill battle for even minor issues and it concerns me that one day, as I get older, I may need their assistance with something more serious because small errors can lead to early warning signs being missed and this surgery seems dogged by these kinds of small errors.

I'm should say (rudeness excepted) I'm sure no-one at the practice is deliberately providing poor service. The GPs and staff seem to work long hours and it must be disappointing for them to receive critical feedback, but service often seems stretched a little thin. Hopefully this can be improved though!

title: Great practice
body: Had a very painful/worrying finger infection and was treated by doctor in A&E, a plastic surgeon. He and his colleagues were absolutely fantastic. Cant praise them enough for the exemplary care and attention I was shown. Calmly going about their usual business while also preparing for corona epidemic. Thank you so much for the brilliant service.

author: CKJKS
title: Outstanding care
body: I received fabulous care in the A&E department, ward 18 and ward 12 in Monklands university hospital. I feel the care I received was outstanding and would like to thank the team in all of the above departments for saving my life

author: S69
title: The staff are doing an excellent job
body: I had to attend the CT Department for a scan. Due to the current problems I was unsure if my scan was going to go ahead but I was told it was. I was extremely grateful that I was getting my scan done as my condition had deteriorated. When I arrived at the Department I was warmly greeted by the lady on the reception desk. Before my scan took place I had to have a cannula inserted as my scan required dye to be put through my body. The man putting the cannula in was friendly and chatty even though they must have been under stress. I was made to feel like an individual and not just another patient. Once inside the scanning room the rest of the staff were also friendly and chatty. Considering the circumstances the staff treated me as an individual and made me feel at ease and comfortable. Everything was explained to me so that I knew exactly what would be happening. The staff in the department are doing an excellent job under difficult circumstances.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)

title: Excellent, modern surgery - great use of…
body: This is a superb, modern surgery with an excellent, caring hard working team. I feel very lucky to have such a high quality practice in the are with latest facilities and the very best healthcare professionals. We know it's always difficult to get an appointment wherever you are, but this is not the fault of the individuals who work tirelessly for us, looking after our health and well being. The demand for their time has increased exponentially, then overlaying this, we're in the midst of an pandemic. Knoll has risen to the challenge with an easy-to-use online 'e-consult' solution for when you REALLY need to see the doctor. I used this recently when I was quite unwell, and I can't praise enough how well this works. Go to the Knoll Practice website, and complete the questions which are well laid out and cleverly adapt to the symptoms you describe. The questions are straight forward and do not take long to complete. You simply submit your answers, you receive confirmation via email and sms, and then you're given a diagnosis or follow up advice next day. I used the service recently, submitting my online form in the evening. I received a response and prescription next day, which was transferred to my pharmacist and I was able to collect my medication same day. Great use of technology, which saves time and does away with the need to go into the surgery which helps everybody. Great idea, well executed. That said, please only use this facility, if you are really unwell. It's a good resource, but we must use it wisely. Well done to all at the Knoll and massive thanks for all the good work you do for the community.

author: Mel mel
title: Requiring an inhaler during this peak time of the virus
body:
Called in to request for an inhaler to help me with my breathing during this corona breakout. I am self isolating away from work also and I work in the nhs also but due to my own health I have to isolate and my breathing is rapidly getting bad. I called the gp practice to request for an inhaler to be told that I will have to wait for 2 days for a prescription. I was not offered a gp to call me to discuss my symptoms or Anything if truth be told. I understand that there is a huge demand for patients needing help but also in order to lower the spread of this virus spreading, the best way to help patients is to hear of their symptoms and then be able to advise them better including sending over a prescription via online to a near chemist so that this could be picked up. I was not calling to be seen as I know I am not able to at present. All I requested was for an inhaler to help with my breathing difficulties I have struggling. Now to wait for 2 days is impossible, suppose I do not make it within two days due to my asthma and my coughing, this feeling already with my chest being so tight is hard enough to deal with much less to bare it more for two days.  
I am writing this on my mother's behalf as I am isolating due to my own health. She cannot be out and just needing support whilst at home through this time. Her symptoms could be part of corona we do not know however she is struggling to breathe and needs an inhaler quickly.

author: bc297
title: Well on my way to recovery
body:
I was referred to Shona at Perinatal Mental Health after a very traumatic birth last summer and I can’t thank her enough for the difference she has made to my life in such a short time.  
When I was first referred to her I had post traumatic stress, was not sleeping and was suffering panic attacks. Shona immediately identified the trauma from my birth and explained it in a way that started to help with things immediately. She helped me with a care plan and liaised with my GP as well as arranging psychotherapy for me.  
Speaking to someone who had the background in midwifery has made all the difference to the recovery of my mental health. Before my very first appointment she had done so much research through what information she had available about me. This made such a huge difference with our first meeting. From the outset it was clear she cared about my situation and I was not just another number.  
I have gone from being absolutely traumatised and severely depressed to feeling like I am well on my way to recovery. Birth trauma is horrific and I am forever grateful the Grampian for providing a trauma specialist as part of their service, especially as one as experienced and fantastic as Shona.

readBy.name: Yorkshire & Humber Patient Safety Research Collaboration

author: AC1979
title: Suspension of therapy amidst the pandemic
body:
I had a therapy session yesterday, via telephone, and was told that my therapy is to be suspended for an unknown time due to the coronavirus pandemic. As much as i understand the reasoning for this, I felt I must explain why, for me, this is terrifying.  
I have been seeing a therapist for nearly a year now. Due to my issues, it is ongoing, with no clear end date as of yet. I came to therapy with crippling anxiety and depression and was also quickly diagnosed with an Anxious Avoidant Personality Disorder. My therapeuric journey is a LIFE-CHANGING journey. It had to be, as I could barely function, was not 'living' due to extreme anxiety and fear etc. It has taken to this point for me to, only just, start changing how I think and deal with life, meaning I am at possibly the most crucial part of my therapy because I am starting to shed my harmful ways of thinking which makes me extremely vulnerable at this point as I am on very unsteady ground. Therapy is like my anchor, and my ONLY truly safe space. It is the only place I can talk about ANYTHING I need to talk about. I cannot just make do with talking to friends or family, if that was a possibility, I would not have had to go to therapy in the first place. I need the therapist/patient dynamic in order to feel I can talk freely, without judgement or shame, and without causing the ones I love extreme concern. Therapy is where I am shown other ways of looking at things, doing things, and shown things in a perspective other than my own that I am unable to see myself. I understand that this crisis is huge, and I understand the extreme pressure on the NHS more than any others, but it is this crisis that makes me feel it is more important than ever to continue my therapy as stopping now will almost certainly prove catastrophic, as I am in a very unsteady place, effectively functioning with a borrowed 'shield'. By 'shield', I mean self-worth/confidence/self-respect and the many other things that allow us to live a fairly healthy well-rounded life.Therapy is my borrowed shield, therapy is where I am constructing my own shield. I am also a 'key-worker' as a home carer which brings it's own anxiety due to the current pandemic and I know that in order to keep working, to keep going outside I need to stay in therapy. My biggest fear just now is not the coronavirus, it is the thought of trying to cope with all of these things on my own. I am fairly certain I can't cope on my own. Which means my mental health may revert to how it was a year ago, barely leaving the house etc, and then become ever more exacerbated by the worldwide crisis. Thank you for your time.

readBy.name: Imperial College, BSc Humanities, Philosophy & Law (2020)
Yorkshire & Humber Patient Safety Research Collaboration

title: Unbelievable care
body: I have just been discharged after spending 6 days as an in patient following an operation. From the support before during and to my discharge I have received nothing but high standards of expertise, compassion and care. I was on post care op for a day and the on ward C18a, where every single member of the team (and they are a genuine team) worked so hard to make me  feel well again. I also include blood labs, pharmacy , Cleaners, food service etc Obviously there are extra pressures these days and all the staff have their own personal issues, but they always put the patients first.  We truly do take them all for granted but perhaps when all this over, we will continue to show genuine appreciation.

title: Reception staff
body: Receptionist very rude and condescending. As first point of contact for your surgery, it creates a very bad impression of your practice

title: Lessons to learn
body:
Having been hospitalised twice in the last 6 weeks I think you need to do something about the care you give to people who are confused or with dementia. 
The care I received was first class and any problems I had I was able to talk to the staff and resolve problems that I was having. 
During my two visits I was able to witness the care confused people or dementia sufferers were given. This can be split into two categories.
1. The patient is unable to let the nurse know what they want, some examples I saw were,
a) The patient was asking to go upstairs and the nurses thought he was really confused and that he was in his own house. He became very agitated and in actual fact he was trying to tell them he wanted to go to the toilet.
b)The patient is in pain and was not able to tell the nurses. During a day shift the patient became very unsettled and was given a strong pain killer by injection. After the night shift came on he started to become unsettled again that by about 1 he was keeping everyone awake and it was suggested that he might need some pain relief. This was duly given and the ward settled.
2 Nurses not being able to handle people with dementia. In this I mean that many nurses will try to restrict the movement of a patient who becomes disturbed. I can understand why they do this to keep the patient safe. This was an almost daily occurrence. As I have experience of this I always found the best way was to distract them and leave for a few minutes. This could be simple operations as taking blood pressures.
My wife who had Alzhimers Had to go into hospital for some weeks. She had to go into a normal ward  and I was disappointed by the care she got. As a result of this I met with the hospital management and they agreed to improve the training given to staff in the handling of patients with dementia.
thanks
